title.narrative: AWD response for WASH and Health in Amhara and Tigray regions Ethiopia

description.narrative:
The WASH and Health intervention proposed will support the immediate needs of the AWD affected communities. The project will focus on life saving interventions via provision of drugs and medicals supplies for CTC , Capacity building of the government health workers safe water (rehabilitation of damaged water supply systems/hand pumps, distribution of point of use of water treatment chemicals and water quality monitoring), hygiene promotion and distribution of WASH Non­food Items (NFIs). This project will have a significant impact on reducing water borne preventable diseases and prevent the occurrence of disease outbreaks, AWD in particular. The project will benefit 33,333 households in Amhara and Tigray region.
The whole program implementation period requires around 777,575.55 USD in which the intervention will target both community level preventive interventions with highest proportion going to WASH and facility level case management support. The program will be based on surveillance, containment and response. A Roving team composed of Health, WASH and Logistic will be based in the field office and deployed to affected districts to provide technical support and overall coordination for the AWD response.. SC closely working in coordinated manner with the health and WASH clusters. SC have broader operational areas and the AWD responses will be implemented in prioritized districts based on, case load, partner’s engagement, operational feasibility and other factors. The primary focus of intervention is WASH focused preventive interventions with targeted/prioritized support to RHB in regard to case management.
The project will enable us to build capacity at National and regional levels health workers for effective prevention, response and control of AWD, thereby to limit the spread to other part of Ethiopia, and reduce the adverse health and socio-economic consequences of AWD outbreak. During an AWD outbreak, the best control measures are early detection of cases and early treatment of patients in established AWD case treatment center (CTCs), combined with effective surveillance. In addition, the mobilization of the community is important for the implementation of the key control measures. The project will prioritize the most vulnerable groups of the affected population such as, pregnant women, lactating mothers, women headed households, elders, people with disabilities and people living with HIV AIDS. The selection criteria will be set in coordination with the kebele leaders. In the selection and prioritization process women will be heavily involved and will have a decision making role. In implementation all groups of the population will be involved. Women will constitute at least fifty percent of the positions of community hygiene promoters, water management committees (WASHCO), Non Food (NFIs) distribution committee and in other activities.
